Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Volatile Organic Compound Sensors using Conducting Polymer and Nanocomposite Blends deposited by Resonant Infrared, Matrix-Assisted Pulsed Laser Evaporation
Award.AbstractNarration:
There is a large number of diabetics for whom a simple breath test to determine glucose abnormalities would be deemed superior to the current standard blood test. Development of a non-invasive method to monitor blood glucose that mirrors the accuracy of the painful blood test would revolutionize not only the lives of diabetics, but also the lives of the physicians who monitor their health. The painful blood test that is currently the standard monitoring method is potentially expensive, and it also deters regular monitoring of glucose - often with dangerous outcomes. It is especially dangerous for diabetics who have hypoglycemia unawareness, in which case, only the glucose test will alert the person to the dangerously low blood sugar levels that can lead to coma or even death.

This work will develop gas sensors for detection of volatile organic compounds (VOCs) in exhaled human breath that act as biomarkers of internal bodily processes, specifically those processes existing uniquely in diabetes patients. The gas sensors comprise organic thin-films deposited by resonant infrared, matrix-assisted pulsed laser evaporation (RIR-MAPLE). RIR-MAPLE provides vastly increased processability and control over a large range of functional organic materials for which few methods exist to effectively fabricate films with nanoscale features.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Development of a non-invasive method to monitor blood glucose that mirrors the accuracy of the painful blood test would revolutionize not only the lives of diabetics, but also the lives of the physicians who monitor their health.  The painful blood test that is currently the standard monitoring method is potentially expensive at $1 per test, but it also deters regular monitoring of glucose – often with dangerous outcomes. A non-invasive test in which a diabetic can simply blow into a device to determine their glucose levels would almost certainly lead to a drop in diabetes-related health emergencies, which would reduce health care costs. 

This work seeks to develop gas sensors for detection of volatile organic compounds (VOCs) in exhaled human breath that act as biomarkers of internal bodily processes, specifically those processes existing uniquely in diabetes patients. The gas sensors comprise organic thin-films deposited by resonant infrared, matrix-assisted pulsed laser evaporation (RIR-MAPLE). RIR-MAPLE could enable this more efficient and less expensive solution to glucose monitoring because the technique can blend organic materials into thin films regardless of solubility and can easily produce a desired ratio of two or more materials.  Moreover, RIR-MAPLE produces rough films that have a high surface area to volume ratio, which more suitably approaches the ideal adsorption profile of a porous film gas sensor.  Therefore, RIR-MAPLE could directly address the desired architecture and functionality of a more elegant solution to glucose monitoring.

The I-Corps team sampled the opinions of current patients, manufacturers, and researchers in the field of diabetic glucose monitoring to determine where market demand would mesh best with the capabilities and outcomes of the RIR-MAPLE process. Participation in the NSF I-Corps Team provided an opportunity to focus on commercialization of the RIR-MAPLE process that has been developed at Duke University, and an application to convert a provisional patent was filed as a result of this effort.  In addition, the entrepreneurship training received by the Entrepreneurial Lead resulted in additional funding to pursue the project after the termination of the NSF I-Corps project.

Finally, proof-of-concept devices were fabricated based on judicious choices of functional organic materials. Blended films of two organic-based materials were deposited with different volume ratios to produce a range of films of varying response, demonstrating the ability to produce a “fingerprint” of a given VOC.    


Last Modified: 10/30/2015
Modified by: Adrienne D Stiff-Roberts

POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Development of a non-invasive method to monitor blood glucose that mirrors the accuracy of the painful blood test would revolutionize not only the lives of diabetics, but also the lives of the physicians who monitor their health. The painful blood test that is currently the standard monitoring method is potentially expensive at $1 per test, but it also deters regular monitoring of glucose – often with dangerous outcomes. A non-invasive test in which a diabetic can simply blow into a device to determine their glucose levels would almost certainly lead to a drop in diabetes-related health emergencies, which would reduce health care costs. This work seeks to develop gas sensors for detection of volatile organic compounds (VOCs) in exhaled human breath that act as biomarkers of internal bodily processes, specifically those processes existing uniquely in diabetes patients. The gas sensors comprise organic thin-films deposited by resonant infrared, matrix-assisted pulsed laser evaporation (RIR-MAPLE). RIR-MAPLE could enable this more efficient and less expensive solution to glucose monitoring because the technique can blend organic materials into thin films regardless of solubility and can easily produce a desired ratio of two or more materials. Moreover, RIR-MAPLE produces rough films that have a high surface area to volume ratio, which more suitably approaches the ideal adsorption profile of a porous film gas sensor. Therefore, RIR-MAPLE could directly address the desired architecture and functionality of a more elegant solution to glucose monitoring. The I-Corps team sampled the opinions of current patients, manufacturers, and researchers in the field of diabetic glucose monitoring to determine where market demand would mesh best with the capabilities and outcomes of the RIR-MAPLE process. Participation in the NSF I-Corps Team provided an opportunity to focus on commercialization of the RIR-MAPLE process that has been developed at Duke University, and an application to convert a provisional patent was filed as a result of this effort. In addition, the entrepreneurship training received by the Entrepreneurial Lead resulted in additional funding to pursue the project after the termination of the NSF I-Corps project. Finally, proof-of-concept devices were fabricated based on judicious choices of functional organic materials. Blended films of two organic-based materials were deposited with different volume ratios to produce a range of films of varying response, demonstrating the ability to produce a "fingerprint" of a given VOC.
